title: Tuesday, 16th January, 2018
bodyHTML:
11:02 am
BE11:03am

Hi! Good morning, welcome, hello. This is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's daily whatever with the things and the stuff.

GBKrona Hola
RA Morgen
Blank canvas good morning everyone
wayneJ Hello
RA yay! Things and Stuff
Soundbuy Bonjour

BE11:09am

Turns out it had £1.6m outstanding debt and £2.5m of anticipated revenue in the second half from Carillion.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

Which rather piles on the problems, and I apologise immediately for that pun. Let me cut to Finncap.

BE11:10am

This uncertainty adds to the difficulties Van Elle has already been experiencing. We now feel the overall level of risk is insufficient to offset the apparent low valuation and move from Buy to Hold. We have downgraded our FY 2018E PBT by £2.9m (24% downgrade) and then assume growth from this base.

FATDAZ @forester here is the list of CLLN recs https://www.marketbeat.com/stocks/LON/CLLN/?MostRecent=0&DefaultTab=Ratings
BE11:10am

Downgraded due to uncertainty. We have downgraded FY 2018E PBT by £1.6m assuming the outstanding debt is not paid and by £1.3m assuming lost profit from planned work for Carillion in H2. Our assumed £1.3m H2 hit represents 50% of the planned H2 revenue and could be derived from either a total loss of the £2.5m revenue but some associated cost savings (group gross profit margin is 35%) or a lower level of work being completed.

Mark Shapland any thoughts on Pearson tomorrow?
11:10 am
BE11:10am

There is now significant uncertainty on forecasts. In this context we believe a FY 2018E P/E of 9x and dividend yield 4% is reasonable, setting an 80p price target.

Forester I fear there will be fair few small and medium sized businesses that fail as a result of Carillion.....leading to a fair few mortgages going unpaid etc. As they were paying on 120, some of the debtor amounts owing were potentially crippling.
FATDAZ @Blank Canvas two characters often referenced in my equity broking days lol
erlkin why is it the FTSE has no joie de vivre?
BE11:12am

(@ROTR: UBS, by setting a 1p target and detailing within a couple of paragraphs that Carillion was in negative equity, probably deserves some praise. But, really, there was no reason to have a buy for some time unless your ECM desk was twisting your arm.)

BE11:12am

(Which doesn't happen, to be clear.)

We apply a 5 month downgrade to FY18 and 7 month downgrade to FY19 forecasts. No announcement has been made about any compensation for early contract termination.

Oh dear, another Woodford favourite

Balance sheet – These EPS downgrades add c0.1x to our net debt/EBITDA forecasts which, including the pension deficit, now sits at 3.2x for both FY18 and FY19. Should acquisitions be part of the new CEO’s transformational plans (to be communicated during 2018), this leverage could bring disposals or a dividend adjustment into the debate.

estrangedcapitalist Ello chaps

Boncoeur @DM; I think Capita should the letter L. That would be a capital idea. Welcome to Markets Live, Dan Mccrum.
Boncoeur *acquire*
FATDAZ on that note should companies be allowed to bid on LT contracts a flat or loss making terms for them ?

Rentokil and G4S are always shedding bits and bobs, but any purchase there will be dilutive because moving stuff into the Capita brand does that.

FATDAZ should say at Flat or

erlkin any insight on what is going on in Saudi Arabia and it's impact on the global economy?
11:19 am
BE11:19am

Here's Morgan Stanley ,,,,,,

DJ any comment JD Sports please?
BE11:20am

This we believe is further evidence of RPA (automation) impacting the business model. Insurance and banks are the leading adopters of RPA to automate processes that have been previously outsourced, so it would make sense that Capita should feel the impact in its L&P business first. Capita announced a £17m payment by an L&P customer to terminate a contract early in 2016, that it was in discussions to potentially end another at 1H17 and has now lost the Prudential UK L&P admin contract to Tata (as “its digital transformation partner”, a role it seems unlikely Capita would be selected for) following its merger of M&G/Prudential. The automation companies we spoke to believe it’s unlikely that the two earlier contract announcements would not relate to a desire to deploy automation (ie RPA enabling it to move processes in-house and automating/Capita not set up to deliver RPA). £80m of revenue and the divisional margins have been 6.5/8.9/8.4% 2016/15/14, so taking an average = 8%, implying £6m of EBITA or c 1% of FY18. However, more importantly we think it also reflects CPI’s relatively weak strategic positioning in an outsourcing industry facing structural challenges from RPA (automation)

BE11:21am

Capita CEO's doing a meet and greet with the sellside tomorrow evening, by the way.

wayneJ Isn't the ex CEO of Capita the Chairman of Purple Bricks? And don't both companies have a shareholder or two in common?

There's no new problems in here, just the old problems. Though the old problems are now getting so bad that debt coventants are once again something to worry about.

CCD is expected to report a "pre-exceptional loss of approximately £120m," which is the upper end of the guidance provided in August 2017 and in line with our forecast. Vanquis appears to be running behind our expectations in terms of new bookings, which suggests our forward forecasts could be negatively impacted.

11:29 am

Impairments still appear to be elevated at Moneybarn. The balance sheet remains stretched, with headroom after accounting for 2018 maturities at £31m.

Have James Hamilton at Numis, who's been bullish for ages.

BE11:33am

We do not believe that ROP was blanket mis-sold like PPI, otherwise the
regulator would have stopped sales at the same time, and the claims management
firms would have triumphed – they didn't. Consequently, we see the risk as being that part of the service provided after the forbearance change in April 2014 should have been provided for free. We believe that this is why the FCA is only focused (their choice) on policies sold after April 2014. With ROP providing two year protection (forbearance is only short term) and much of its value being credit score protection, we believe most of its value is not covered by the required forbearance. The claims penetration for PPI after a decade of intense advertising is less than half and CPP penetration is a third after all customers were written to. Consequently, we believe our 50% forecast claim rate with the FCA deeming that 50% of the service should have been provided for free is conservative. This translates to a £108m cost (including compound interest at 39.9%).

FATDAZ @Boncouer agreed
BE11:33am

With the No.2 provider having the capacity to take a maximum of less than 3% of Provident's HCC business, we believe only Provident can substantially and permanently reduce its scale. We believe the HCC business can be turned around and very high returns restored even if the business is much smaller. In HCC scale and returns are not strongly linked.

11:33 am
BE11:34am

That's the gist. Talk to Numis directly if you want more.

Saudi is emerging from a period of transition in its political system from one built
on consensus with (and patronage for) a large royal family and clerical
establishment and social welfare for the mass population, to one built on the
concentration of power in a small group of decision makers, the removal of
subsidies for the elite, the marginalisation of the clerics and the gradual
substitution of security guarantees and populism for welfare for the mass
population.

DM11:37am

The single largest disagreement we have with consensus is on Saudi. We believe
valuations and trading volumes which are at significant discounts to the historic
average provide an attractive entry point given the healthier oil price backdrop
and the successful centralisation of power which is enabling much faster
decision-making.

While Netflix has ruled itself out of the bidding, and has shown no sign of interest in sports rights in other markets, this is not the case for Amazon

Berenberg thinks Amazon will win at least one package of rights, for a number of reasons

BE12:02pm

We expect core inflation in most major economies to grind slowly higher in response to this growth vigour, and this should ‘eventually’ trigger a more proactive effort from central banks to tighten monetary policy. However, we note there are few reasons – at present – either for central banks to throttle inflation or fend off financial imbalances. This means a shift from ‘reactive’ policies to ‘proactive’ policies seems unlikely for the time being. Rhetoric from the BOJ and ECB probably holds the key to when these Goldilocks conditions could start to fade. Allied to this, inflation surprises, together with pricing in fixed income markets, are also of some importance. However, if a capex renaissance can combine with a productivity renaissance and mute capacity pressures while keeping unit wage cost inflation at bay, Goldilocks could hang around for longer than investors may be assuming.

BE12:02pm

As for our forecasts for monetary policy, we still expect the Federal Reserve to raise short-term interest rates three times this year (and once more in 2019). We also expect the ECB to cease its asset purchase programme from September and raise short-term rates by 10bp in December. We further expect the Bank of England to raise rates by a cumulative 50bp in 2018 as well. However, an important exception to this global trend toward policy normalisation is likely to be in Japan, where we see little scope for the BOJ to withdraw policy stimulus.

12:02 pm
BE12:03pm

Turning to EM, we expect the sweet spot of solid growth and strong capital inflows to continue, underpinned by the synchronised global growth recovery, favourable terms of trade (oil prices for LatAm and parts of EEMEA, chip prices for Asia), a stable China and the ongoing global hunt for yield, as DM bond buying by the ECB and BOJ (and by EM central banks via FX intervention) more than offsets the Fed’s quantitative tightening. We are, however, cognisant that large capital inflows to EM have a nasty habit of suddenly reversing, particularly when there are sizable financial imbalances and when compensation for credit risks (e.g., corporate credit spreads) are near historic lows. However, for now, the EM sweet spot continues.

BE12:03pm

In China, hats off to policymakers for pulling off what has so far been an orderly financial deleveraging and economic rebalancing from investment to consumption, but this is not the time to rest on their laurels. Keep an eye on Asia’s tiger cubs – India, Indonesia and the Philippines – the region’s new, rising stars in terms of cyclical
and structural economic upturns. Asian headline inflation could start surprising on the upside in coming months, yet we expect central banks to remain hesitant given high debt levels and lacklustre domestic demand relative to exports in several economies. In LatAm by contrast we expect inflation to remain unusually low in most countries; Brazil and Mexico are both subject to election risk, while Mexico is subject to NAFTA renegotiation
risk, which will likely have major binary macro outcomes. In EEMEA, we expect a divide
to open up, with inflation pressures in Romania, Poland, Hungary and Turkey while most
other countries face more muted inflation outlooks, notably in South Africa, Nigeria and
Russia. The focus will be on politics in all its forms – a reformist policy turnaround in South Africa after President Zuma’s exit, Turkey’s domestic politics and relations with the EU and US; and election cycles in Hungary, Nigeria and Egypt.

Europe rather than US

DM12:04pm

The ECB's Survey of Professional Forecasters supports the ECB’s view that inflation in the Eurozone will pick up and will be back within the central bank's target range in 2019. This column disagrees. Using a model that formalises the widely held view that inflation dynamics are a function of three components – long-term expectations, the Phillips curve, and oil price movement – it forecasts Eurozone inflation in 2019 at only 1.1%, a rate which is close to that implied by the bond markets.
